channel.title: What does this mean?
channel.description: i was following dayles tutorial on how to make a server, and he said this. "Now what you need to do is edit these, to where your java path is and your ant path is, so for e.g where you placed your apache ant folder, go into untill u get to the directory '' C:\apache-ant-1.7.0\bin '' and same with the java, C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06. Just edit the text from C:\ on wards, do not change the set PATH= etc.." and i didnt rlly know what he was talking about, and i think thats Y my servers not running? :s, idk..

item.title: What does this mean?
item.dc:creator: @adu adu
item.description:
@adu wrote:

Jpark:

so it be “java_home=c:\program files\java\jdk1.6.0_10”?

indeed.

Read full topic

so it be “java_home=c:\program files\java\jdk1.6.0_10”?

item.title: What does this mean?
item.dc:creator: @adu adu
item.description:
@adu wrote:

Ok, what it means is that when you edit your run_server.bat or run_ls.bat or compile.bat

your “PATH=” is where you downloaded apache. So for example, say you downloaded and extracted apache in c:\users\username\desktop\apache-ant-1.7.0.

your “PATH=C:\users\username\desktop\apache-ant-1.7.0\bin”

and if you downloaded and extracted apache and in your c:

your “PATH=C:\apache-ant-1.7.0\bin”

Same goes for the JAVA_HOME

your default “JAVA_HOME=C:\Program Files\Java\jdkx.x.x_xx” The “x” represents your jdk version number

Read full topic

@Jpark wrote:

i was following dayles tutorial on how to make a server, and he said this. “Now what you need to do is edit these, to where your java path is and your ant path is, so for e.g where you placed your apache ant folder, go into untill u get to the directory ‘’ C:\apache-ant-1.7.0\bin ‘’ and same with the java, C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_06. Just edit the text from C:\ on wards, do not change the set PATH= etc…” and i didnt rlly know what he was talking about, and i think thats Y my servers not running? :s, idk…
